newsitem.title: CHINA: PRESS DIGEST - HK newspaper headlines - July 17.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - HK newspaper headlines - July 17.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Hong Kong press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

-- MING PAO -- About 13,000 quota spots for mainland Chinese children to be reunited with their Hong Kong parents were used for other purposes over the past three and a half years. Former legislator James To demanded an explanation from the government.

-- APPLE DAILY -- The foreign affairs department of China's Xinhua news agency in Hong Kong will be closed in October and all its staff sent home. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs' Hong Kong Commission preferred to use its own team.
-- The People's Liberation Army's Hong Kong garrison has started to contact Hong Kong government officials on details of laws and regulations relating to the Chinese troops.

-- ECONOMIC JOURNAL -- China's Securities Regulatory Commission said several state-owned enterprises needed to be re-organised to fall into line with the general restructuring of the nation's economy. Big groups would be formed through mergers and acquisitions.

-- TA KUNG PAO -- China Resources said accusations in the United States that the company was involved in non-commercial activities there were unfounded and that it had hired American lawyers to take legal action.

-- EXPRESS NEWS -- A peasant in Guangxi province became a cadre by forging qualifications and Communist Party membership documents. He hid his background and took bribes of 200,000 yuan. Authorities realised he was a con man only after he was caught in a bribery case and stripped of his party membership.
-- SOUTH CHINA MORNING POST -- A new Sino-Taiwan row was looming after the island's lawmakers backed planned constitutional changes that would weaken its status as a province of China.
-- HONGKONG STANDARD -- China's Securities Regulatory Commission has given the go-ahead to the restructuring plan of China Telecom, a company executive said.
